div.p: In my last post, I stated a main goal of mine was to visualization human summaries. After talking with Prof. Jeff Heer this past week, I’ve developed a more concrete goal for this segment of my project.
If we are able to develop a method for approximating human ‘attention’ between source and summary, we can use it in the following ways.

ol.li: Evaluation tool. Current evaluation requires reading article, summary, and thinking critically to map between the two in order to determine whether or not the summary is ‘good’.

Enable cross-model comparison and analysis. How do different models produce summaries for the same article? Automatic measures, such as Rouge and Meteor, are generally poor indicators of proper quality. Currently, one may read summaries and source text and attempt to qualify proper coverage of key ideas. By introducing a visualization that can be generated from any source-summary pair, we can enable more principled analysis.

Enable model to human comparison and analysis. This I discussed in the previous post. What do human summaries have that our models are missing? Missing coverage? Missing entities? This visualization tool could answer these questions.

p.strong: In general, this tool would allow researchers to gain insights about both human and machine summaries.

div.p: With this in mind, I’ll go into the approaches I’ve been experimenting with in the past week.
Last week, I attempted token-on-token similarity. The results can be seen the gif below. The weight between input and output token x and y, respectively, can be described as so:

Where similarity is calculated using a standard word embedding API (in this case, spaCy). The issue with this approach was that context is lost, and so a word will often attend to nearly the entire document with no regard to the ideas coming out of each portion (in summaries, we expect a sentence or phrase to summarize a specific part or few parts of the original document).
div.figure: Token-on-token similarity pays no heed to context — problematic.
div.p: In attempt to remedy this, I added a factor to each weight that represents the similarity of the tokens’ respective sentences. That is, the weight of a given x, y pair is determined by the similarity of the sentence of x and the sentence of y, multiplied by the similarity of the tokens themselves. To both normalize weights (over output token) and exaggerate salient pairs, I also add a soft-max transformation for each similarity score. The equation below describes this formula.
The theta terms here are important in properly exaggerating salient pairs, and so require some tuning.
div.figure: Hierarchical Similarity shows some promise, but has a few issues.
div.p: This approach shows some promise. Context is taken into account, at least at a sentence-by-sentence level. However, there are a few shortcomings that become apparent with more abstractive summaries. In particular:

ul.li: Context is better but far from perfect. Sometimes ideas span multiple sentences, difficult to model. Additionally, repeating words in a sentence get equal ‘attention’ even though one may make more sense from a token-by-token generation standpoint.

div.p: I’ll be exploring this approach further in the next week, but I have concerns about its ability to generalize well, per issues described above.

At a high level, we can imagine ‘attention’ as the words and phrases from the source text to that one would draw from to write a portion of a summary. This makes sense: we tend to focus on specific areas of a document at a time when writing summaries. Breaking this into token-by-token time-steps, summary token is conditioned on the ‘attention’ vector for that time-step.
div.figure: Summary tokens are conditioned on attention vectors over the source text.
div.p: Further, we can reason that attention vectors change from time-step to time-step, dependent on the previous attention vector.
div.figure: Attention vectors are conditioned on each other.
div.p: This of course is an simplification — the way our minds work is likely far more complex — but it allows us to model the ‘attention’ between source and summary as a Hidden Markov Model (HMM).
div.figure: Source to summary modeled as a Hidden Markov Model.
div.p: We can then use this model to predict attention vectors at each time-step (e.g. Viterbi, Forward-Backward). This is similar to how HMMs are used to predict part-of-speech tags (where POS tags are conditioned on each other and tokens are conditioned on those tags). Emissions (the edge weight going from distribution to summary token) can be defined by token similarity, but there are still a challenges here.

ol.li: How to define transition probabilities?
Treat attention states as distributions or single tokens (e.g. argmax in vector)?

div.p: I’ll need to consider this approach further to see if I can work out these kinks.
I’ve also been slowly improving the visualization tool itself. I’ll briefly describe my progress on this front.

Using NLTK, I was able to part-of-speech tag machine-generated summaries. At the top right of the visualization, users are presented a panel of the POS Tags used by the Penn Tree Bank, which NLTK sources from. Non-present tags are greyed-out.
div.figure: Users can highlight tokens to view the corresponding tag, or mouse over tags to highlight all corresponding tokens.
div.p: This should allow more in-depth analysis of the attention vectors produced by the machine. Eventually I’d like to work towards highlighting named entities in the source / summary to allow users to identify present / missing ideas centered on important entities.

ol.li: Continue working on visualizing source-summary alignment.
Continue improving visualization.

div.p: I have lots, lots, lots to do. Until next time!

div.span: Social Media Predicts Stock Price (StartUp Mode)

The drawback of News Tweets

Some news tweets don’t summarize well for the real content and cause misleading predictions.
The sources of such news tweets are mostly unauthorized.
Therefore, we decided to move on and explore new news sources which are authorized as our input.

We used the financial news published everyday and crawl the content directly, instead of using the titles. This will increase the input size for each news. However, it helps the model to gain more information from each single news.
The link to the source we use:
Model Optimization
Add learning rate decay to our training
This helps the model to converge smoothly at the end of training
Investigate the correlation between sentiment analysis of Tweets and stock price movement
We categorize the attitudes in each tweets and news, which increase our feature size
Also, we compare the overall attitudes of all tweets and news each day with the prediction made by the model and the real stock price.
Visualize and investigate our prediction/training to have better understanding of our model
Find out the top k words that have most weight for a given day
Most of them do not seem to relate to stock price movement
Compare the prediction/target graph for each epochs to see if the predictions are improving/converging
Graphs:
Predict more stock prices in the further future rather than just the next day.
Implement an application to help optimize investment strategy

div.p: I’ll keep this blogpost short — my current undertakings are in-progress and it might be a week or more before they are realized. To preface:

ol.li: Visualizing human summaries
Improving the visualization.

div.p: When I was presenting my project update last week, Prof. Choi asked a very interesting question. What if we could use this visualization tool to not only understand how the model is generating summaries, but also how human summaries are produced and how the two compare?
I’ll briefly explain the thought behind this.

Visualizations provide a mapping from raw data (in this case, attention weights and input / output tokens) to visual encodings. These visual encodings are valuable in that they allow us as humans to perceive the data in a meaningful way. For example, the attention visualizer I am working on allows us to identify overall patterns in the attention of the model.

How do we interpret human written summaries, i.e. their relation to the source text? Perhaps we scan the document and attempt to match paragraphs or sentences to sentences in the summary. This can be compared to the ‘attention’ our minds use to generate the summary. If we can visualize this mapping, perhaps in a more refined and detailed manner (i.e. token by token) then we should be able to compare the human summaries with the machine generated summaries, right? And then one may be able to identify what the human summaries have that the machine summaries do not, or visa versa. The hope is that if we can enable this kind of comparison, researchers may be better equipped to improve their models by using these insights.
So far, I’ve experimented with two methods for generating this ‘attention’ from human summary to source text.

The first approach that sprung to mind was to use word similarity as a proxy for ‘attention’. To do this, I used pre-trained GloVe embeddings and the Gensim API to calculate word similarities between each input token / output token pair. SpaCy was used to tokenize the sequences. The result is a matrix of weights, similar to attention distribution, albeit not normalized per output token (with attention, for a given output token the aggregate over all input tokens is 1). As the example below shows, this method falls flat, as output tokens are matched to input tokens regardless of context. This means it makes little sense to compare these weights to attention.
div.figure: The word ‘the’ is matched with nearly every token in the input sequence, likely a result of its extreme commonness and proximity to most words in embedding space.
div.p: The second method I considered was one suggested by Ari. Here, we use the same model used to generate the machine summaries. The difference is that at each decoder time-step, instead of feeding in the previous predicted token, we feed in the previous actual token. This means that instead of having a decoding pipeline that looks like this:
Where y-hats represent predicted output tokens, we have one that looks like this:
Where y (no hat) represents true output token (the token from the human summary). This is a process similar to the one taken during training of generative encoder-decoder models.

By grabbing attention distributions just as we had with the machine summaries, we hope to get an approximation of the attention distributions for the human summaries — we are essentially feeding the model the answer. However, there is a catch, and an important one. Because attention weights are used to create a context vector that is then fed into the next decoder unit to predict the next word, we run into an issue when the next word is predicted incorrectly. Turns out, this happens often under the model being used (from See et al.). This actually makes sense, as the model has been shown to produce largely extractive summaries, and so one would expect the model to, at each time-step, attempt to produce the next word in the source text that follows the word fed to it. With abstractive summaries, this is not often the optimal choice. This results in attention weights that make little sense, as seen below.
div.figure: According to this, ‘manager’ was the focal point of attention when producing the word ‘were’. It would seem that the model intended to predict ‘manager’, and so when we map this attention weight to the human token, we run into an issue.
div.p: Here’s the problem. The model is trained to use attention weights to generate an output token. What we want is the opposite. We want the attention given an output token — use the output token to generate the attention weights. This poses a significant challenge.

So neither of these methods seem to produce anything meaningful. I’m not ready to give up though — this is an intriguing problem. In the next week I’ll be brainstorming other methods. One that might have some traction is to use a few heuristics to approximate ‘attention’ using word similarities in conjunction with context. For example, by imposing a penalty on the weight if the context of the output token is dissimilar to the word ‘attended’ to in the source text. Much more work to be done here.
This section will be short. There are a few problems I looked into in the past week.

ol.li: Implement divided edge bundling, as produced by Selassie et al. (2011). I described this briefly in my previous blog post. The obstacle here is that there is not available d3 implementation of the algorithm. In fact, the only implementation I could find available was one for Matlab, produced by Kelly Kearny (University of Washington). This might prove more difficult than the remaining time in this quarter allows, but I’ve started the process anyways and will see where it takes me.

Highlighting extraction. That is, making it apparent in the visualization when the model is simply copying. I’ve been playing around with things such as color to encode this, but haven’t settled on anything I like.

div.p: More work to come!

li.a: See, Abigail et al. “Get To The Point: Summarization with Pointer-Generator Networks.” ACL (2017).
Selassie, David et al. “Divided Edge Bundling for Directional Network Data.” IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics 17 (2011): 2354–2363.

h4.span: Team members: Dawei Shen, Pinyi Wang, Xukai Liu

div.span: Social Media Predicts Stock Price (StartUp Mode)

span.b: Try Out Logistic Regression To Tune LSTM

span.span: From our previous model, which we classify the stock price movement as UP/DOWN/STAY, we noticed that during training often the loss will converge in less than 5 epochs and the predictions are either all UPs or all STAYs depending on the range of percent difference we classified as STAY. It seems like the model wasn’t able to learn much from the input data.

Then, we tried to use logistic regression by making our RNN only has one output node and remove the softmax function. We also changed the loss function from Cross-Entropy to mean squared loss. This helps to predict the percentage of change of the stock price directly.

With the new training method, the model can now predict a specific stock price for a day given input data. Then, according to the stock price predicted, we can further categorize the prediction into UP/DOWN/STAY and use our previous evaluation function to determine the accuracy of our model.

span.b: Select and Add Competitors Stock Price to Tune LSTM

span.span: For company Apple, we selected company Samsung’s and Huawei’s stock prices as part of input data to train the model, because this two big company also produce mobile phones and are the biggest competitors for Apple in the industry.
For company Tesla, we selected company Toyota for the similar reason as for Apple.

After we have improved the model and the training process, it no longer generates the same classification for all input. It now does try to predict the stock price percent difference and has reasonable results.
The prediction accuracy for Apple will be around
% if we choose
‘+/-0.5% change of the stock price
as
‘STAY’.
The prediction accuracy for Apple will be above
% if we choose
‘+/-1.0% change of the stock price’
as
‘STAY’.

span.b: What to Investigate for the Next Week

span.span: Try to use CNN as model.
Instead of using Tweets, try using financial news as input.
Try out different embedding methods.
Apply F1 Scores. For the evaluation, we would like to know:
The rate of stocks are marked ‘UP’/’DOWN’/’STAY’ that are predicted correctly as ‘UP’/’DOWN’/’STAY’ separately.
The rate of stocks are marked ‘UP’/’DOWN’/’STAY’ that are predicted wrongly as ‘UP’/’DOWN’’STAY’

div.p: A couple of developments since I last posted:

ol.li: I’m now more formally receiving guidance from Kanit (Ham) Wongsuphasawat and Tongshuang (Sherry) Wu of the Interactive Data Lab. Special thanks to them for helping me thus far!

Last week I was uncertain as to the future direction of this project. After much deliberation and several conversations, I’ve decided to remain on the tool-based approach originally conceived. There are a couple reasons for this. First, the user study I proposed has, at least from an NLP perspective, limited novelty. What’s more, learning from the study by modifying the underlying model would require time that would likely fall outside of the quarter. Second, carrying out this study would involve significant logistical work (again, a time constraint). Finally, in beginning to formalize this visualization tool, I’ve become more excited in its potential as a useful part of a researcher’s debugging pipeline. In any case, any model modifications I may make as part of the user study would difficult without a similar tool.
As mentioned, I’ve been formalizing this tool in a React application, iterating on the exploration I’ve done with prototypes in the weeks previous. The rest of this post will describe my work here.

div.p: First things first: text brushing is critical in understanding the attention each output token, or a series of output tokens, pays to the source text. In the gif below, the left side holds the source text (along with a mini-map to prevent the need of scrolling to understand the overall distribution of attention), while the right holds the summary. Selection and brushing have been implemented, as in the prototypes of last week, albeit cleaned up.
div.figure: Cleaned up selection and brushing, in addition to a minimap for long input sequences.

ol.li: Sentence / paragraph level structure is lost via tokenizing. This is an artifact of the tokenization process performed prior to feeding text into models.

Lowercase and always-on spacing between tokens makes text difficult to read. For now, I’ve been dealing this with a few hand-coded rules. For example, removing spaces before punctuation, and capitalizing the first word after end of sentence punctuation.

div.p: I’ll need to keep brainstorming to find methods for addressing these issues.
div.h4: How do we enable identification of patterns?
div.p: While selection and brushing over the text is valuable in allowing users to understand attention for specific words or phrases, it falls short in enabling big-picture identification of patterns. Without brushing over each token and / or sentence (and memorizing coverage along the way), the closest users may get is the aggregate view (when nothing is selected) in which what is being attended to is apparent, but not how. That is to say, it is not apparent which tokens / phrases in the summary attend to which tokens / phrases in the source text. In particular, below is a growing list of goals for this visualization.

ol.li: Enable identification of coverage. For words / phrases / sentences, where is the attention being paid, and by what?
Enable identification of missing coverage. What is being unattended to that should be?
Enable identification of extraction vs abstraction. Where is copying occuring? Where is true abstraction occuring?

div.p: If this tool can accomplish these items, I believe it will be a good start in proving its value.
With this in mind, we need some sort of visualization to accompany the two blocks of text. As previously mentioned, heat-maps may not be the best solution.
div.figure: Interactive heat-map, as prototyped previously.
div.p: Lag is apparent (likely a result of the large number of elements drawn), and even ignoring this, the tiles become extremely small as the input / output sequences grow, making it difficult to pick out even high attention weights. More visual weight is needed for significant attention weights, which is difficult to accomplish as x and y space is already taken by the input / output token position.

p.strong: So where else can we look?

div.p: Looking back at my project proposal, I saw this visualization made by Rikters et al. (2017).
div.figure: An example of a flow-map from machine translation [Rikters et al. 2017].
div.p: I thought this might be worth exploring, so I attempted to create something similar.
div.figure: A flowmap displaying all edges is problematic. This doesn’t scale either.
div.p: Unsurprisingly, there are far too many edges to display without significant overlap and occlusion. Summarization rears its head again as a challenge with its large input sequences.

One observation is that high attention weights are fairly sparse (as evident by the aggregate on the source text above). What if we filtered out these insignificant weights? A naive approach is to take the top k percent of weights and display only those.
div.figure: A flowmap showing only the top 1% of weights.
div.p: The above example is displaying only the top 1% of attention weights. Edges have both their width and opacity scaled by their weight within this 1% domain. Significant (wide) weights are clearly identifiable. Thinner lines, faint (or nearly invisible) lines can also be seen, indicating that the much more significant weights have been preserved. Four distinct ‘rays’ can be seen, seemingly corresponding to the four sentence of the summary.
Selection and brushing seemed like intuitive follow-ups for interaction to enable more detailed / accurate pattern identification.
div.figure: Selection over the flowmap, both over the output nodes as well as the output text.
div.p: Selection allows users to orient themselves in the flowmap, picking out which edges correspond to which input / output tokens.
div.figure: Brushing over the flowmap allows for windowed pattern identification.
div.p: Brushing enables accurate pattern identification. In the example above, brushing over the distinct rays allows us to see the almost entirely extractive nature of the summary — there is a clear 1:1 mapping from input to output that is implied by the clean structure of the rays, and confirmed upon inspecting the corresponding input / output tokens for these rays.

ol.li: Selecting a top k% is not ideal — it does not generalize well. In the pathological case, where attention is evenly distributed for all tokens, we lose a lot of valuable information. A potential band-aid to this is to allow users to select the percentage of weights displayed, but this may be dangerous as high percentages can crash the browser. Perhaps a more elegant solution would be to perform clustering on the weights. I’ll need to do more research here.

Overlapping paths can make reading the flowmap difficult. The example shown above is fairly clean, direction flows, for the most part, in a single direction. You could imagine, however that if a summary is extremely abstractive, pulling from all over the source, there might be significant overlap in edges, decreasing legibility. A potential solution to this is edge bundling, where edges going in similar directions are pulled together to preserve pattern recognition.

div.p: A good starting point for exploration here is the paper Divided Edge Bundling for Directional Network Data by Selassie, Heller, & Heer (2011). In this, the authors describe a method for bundling, divided edge bundling, that holds characteristics I believe are important for my own visualization.
div.figure: Different techniques applied to a network of GitHub contributions along the west coast of the United States [Selassie, Heller, & Heer 2011].
div.p: In the coming weeks I hope to dive into these techniques and explore their impact on the flowmap I’ve developed thus far.
Still a lot of work to do! Here are my goals for the next week.

ol.li: Improve flowmap visualization.
Find examples that cover the problem space (e.g. low coverage, abstraction, extraction).
Keep brainstorming.
Optimize code.

div.p: Things are getting interesting!

li.a: Rikters, Matīss, Mark Fishel, and Ondřej Bojar. “Visualizing neural machine translation attention and confidence.” The Prague Bulletin of Mathematical Linguistics 109.1 (2017): 39–50.
Selassie, David et al. “Divided Edge Bundling for Directional Network Data.” IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics 17 (2011): 2354–2363.

source.subtitle: Stories by Halden Lin on Medium
source.title: Stories by Halden Lin on Medium

div.p: previous posts: 01 02 03 04 05

I’ve begun to realize I may not be getting as much out of the project I chose I had hoped. My initial motivation for my project was a hope of expanding my knowledge and developing insights on the NLP front by leveraging the familiarity of Visualization. While I am certainly learning a lot by reading papers on Attention and Neural Networks as a whole (especially through my in-class paper presentation), I feel the work I am doing in building a tool for visualizing and debugging attention models may not be providing me the space to explore NLP that I had hoped for. While the tool will certainly enable exploration, my concern is that this exploration will not occur until after the tool is completed at the end of the quarter.
The good news is that there have been two recent developments that, while increasing my uncertainty, offer potential for greater depth in exploration along the NLP front.
I voiced these concerns with Prof. Choi this past week and was given a good amount of valuable advice. Per her suggestion, the beginning of my last cycle began with three tasks.

ol.li: Read The Efficacy of Human Post-editing for Language Translation, authored by Spence Green, Jeff Heer, and Christopher Manning. This paper is unique in that it presents the value of Visualization and HCI within Natural Language Processing, but not as a window into a model. Rather, the authors explore a specific task integral to the Language Translation pipeline and present suggestions for future work in improving Language Translation.

Do in-depth human error-analysis of existing summarization models. I used examples from See et al.’s paper Get To The Point: Summarization with Pointer-Generator Networks (2017).This was helpful gaining a better intuition as to the problem space and the challenges currently posed by machine summarization.

Think about how summarization as a task, whether that be the development of models, the model’s task itself, or end-user tasks that use the model, can be re-framed in order to leverage Visualization. This was especially time consuming, as it was difficult for me, but it helped immensely in taking a step back to understand the purpose of these models. This, in turn, helped me understand how my work can fit into this purpose.

div.p: The next few days consisted largely of brainstorming pivots for my project. The most promising direction that came out of these sessions is very briefly outlined below.

Machine-generated document summaries, even the state-of-the-art, are infrequently used in practice because their summaries are quite poor. Perhaps we can leverage existing models to, rather than produce definite summaries which may be error-prone or difficult to understand, create visualizations over the source text in order to assist humans in comprehension and abstraction.

For example, instead of treating attention weights as input for an output of text, as we do in summarization models, we can view them as output for human interpretation. Aggregate attention distributions (in summarization) highlight areas of the input text that are salient for the summary produced. Note that this is potentially more valuable than highlighting extractive summaries in the text because attention could potentially point towards different areas of the text that relate to a summary sequence. In this way, generation of summaries becomes a proxy task for creating salient highlights for text. We could then use this as a starting point from which ‘related’ sections in an article may be highlighted for users upon interaction (e.g. mousing over an attended-to sequence).
The hope is that these visualizations will increase the speed (over no summarization) or accuracy (over machine summarization) at which readers can abstract / understand key ideas in a document.

Most excitingly, with this re-framing of the task for these models, from sequence output to highlighting, perhaps the models can be modified by adding or removing constraints and mechanisms in order to improve performance for this new task.

Upon presenting this idea (in longer form) to Prof. Choi, I was encouraged to (1) think more about weaknesses of removing summaries altogether and (2) push for more novelty in the approach — is there any meaningful insight about attention models or summarization as a task that can be gleamed from this pivot, and if not, how can I work towards that. While I do not yet have answers to these concerns, the next development may result in a few.
div.h4: 2. Related work, here at the Allen School
div.p: It was just recently brought to my attention that a Tongshuang (Sherry) Wu, a PhD student in the Interactive Data Lab (in which I am currently working), is also working on visualizations for understanding attention models in NLP. As a part of her project, she and a few of her peers have developed a preliminary visualization tool for an attentive QA model (on the SQuAD dataset).She and my mentor, Kanit (Ham) Wongsuphasawat (whom I have been bouncing ideas off recently), have kindly offered to meet and discuss her work and insights on the problem space. Perhaps collaboration is a possibility — this is exciting! In any case, I suspect talking with Sherry and Ham will provide me the insight and guidance to make a decision on the direction of my project.
I hope to make another blog post in the coming few days as I iron out a future direction. Before this, however, future work is unclear. Until next time!

I’ve also been playing around with my visualization prototypes, even as I am uncertain as to whether or not they will be relevant to my project after this week. Here’s what I’ve discovered and implemented in that time.

ol.li: Interactive heat-maps likely won’t work.

div.figure: Interactive heat-maps result in a large degree of lag between input and visual update. This is likely due to the extremely large size of the attention matrix in summarization (24,000 individual squares in the heat-map).
div.p: This is unfortunate, but browser limitations are limitations that must be worked around.
2. Selection over output text.
div.figure: Mousing over words in the summary results in a view of the attention distribution over the article for that decoder time-step.
div.p: This is similar to the interactive visualizations presented by See et al. in their blogpost.
3. Brushing over output text.
div.figure: Brushing over the summary results in an aggregate attention distribution (i.e. coverage) over the article for the selected decoder time-steps.
div.p: This is an interaction technique I have yet to see in work involving attention analysis, so this is exciting! It looks to be somewhat useful in identifying sections of input text that are salient to an idea rather than a single word in the output text.

h4.span: Team members: Dawei Shen, Pinyi Wang, Xukai Liu

div.span: Social Media Predicts Stock Price (StartUp Mode)

span.span: This week, we added more data source and have finer process of the data. We also convert
Keras model to Tensorflow for better future improvement.

li.span: We updated our code from using Keras to Tensorflow which helps to do more improvement on model. For example, TensorFlow is a lower level library which allow us to have more control over the variables we used as the input and output. For example, if we want to try with more complicated input with adding the voerall market stock price and the competitors' stock prices, TensorFlow will be more helpful.

span.b: Add One More Target Company: Tesla

li.span: As there are too many Tweets that have tagged #Apple but are unrelated to the company Apple, we need to filter out such tweets. However, if we apply the model on the company Tesla, who's company name is uniquer than 'Apple' and has its products naming closer to its company name, the Tweets and news that have tagged #Tesla will contain much less noisy information and thus improve the prediction to its stock price.

span.b: Try Out Different Layers Structure to Tune LSTM

span.span: Add the NASDAQ index to the input
The composition of the NASDAQ Composite is heavily weighted towards information technology companies. Therefore, company Apple’s and Tesla’s stock prices may be influenced by the Nasdaq index.
Add a 'STAY' category as the output prediction of stock price
If the change of the stock price for the next day is within 1%, we will mark the stock price of that day as a ‘STAY’. Otherwise, we mark it as ‘UP’ or ‘DOWN’
Lemmatization & Stemming
Lemmatization and stemming help collect the same words with different tenses together, which reduce the total vocabulary size.
After we have improved the model and the training process, the prediction accuracy for Apple will be above 85% if we choose '+/-1% change of the stock price' as 'STAY'.
The prediction accuracy for Apple will be above 60% if we choose '+/-1% change of the stock price' as 'STAY'.

span.b: What To Investigate For The Next Week

span.span: Apply F1 scores. For the evaluation ,we would like to know:
The rate of stocks are marked 'UP/DOWN/STAY' that are predicted correctly as 'UP/DOWN/STAY' separately.
The rate of stocks are marked 'UP/DOWN/STAY' that are predicted wrongly as 'UP/DOWN/STAY' separately.
Add competitors' stock prices to the input

div.p: Hi! Here’s what I’ve been up to in the past week.
Real data collection and the backend are functioning!
div.figure: Architecture of the Attention Plugin.
div.p: At this point last week, I had implemented the nodes in green above. These were the operators / functions required to produce Summary protobufs that are in turn saved to disk.
This week, I completed a number of tasks to produce a bare-bones functioning plugin (sans visualizations).
First, I modified the source code for See et al.’s (2017) attentional models to use the Attention Plugin API to save input text, output text, and attention distributions during evaluation.
Next, I implemented the Attention Plugin’s back-end, which is used to fulfill requests made by the front-end. This service currently offers two services:

ol.li: tags This route returns all tags associated for each run in the log. This should include 3 tags for each run: one for each of the input, output, and attention tensors.

attention This route returns a list values associated with the given tag (including time and step stamps). This can be used by the front-end to acquire each of the input, output, and attention lists (converted from tensors) by passing the corresponding tag (retrieved using the tags route).

div.p: Finally, as a proof of concept, I modified the front-end provided in the TensorBoard Plugin Example to consume this back-end, showing it is able to retrieve summaries. Now we just need some visualizations to consume the data!

While data collection and back-end development has been wrapping up, I’ve begun to prototype static visualizations for the plugin. To do this, I used data produced by See et al.’s (2017) pre-trained attentional models (produced only at decode time without the Attention Plugin). Through this process, I hope to gain two things in particular.

ol.li: A idea of what will/won’t work as visualizations for summarization tasks.
A better understanding of the behavior of attentive models, and through that a better idea of how static and/or interactive visualizations can further interpretability and understanding.

div.p: The first idea I decided to pursue was that of a condensed heat-map. You may recall the conventional heat-map used for attention visualizations described in my first blog post.
div.figure: Rikters et al. (2017). A heat-map with relatively large cells, allowing for display of text along the axes.
div.p: The issues I noted with this visualization pattern are as follows:

ol.li: It is difficult to fit the words (as seen above) on the x-axis, harming readability.
This does not scale well with large input or output (e.g. summarization)
We do not read single-tokens at a time (i.e. y-axis), and input and output are generally not in this format either.

div.p: To address the point (2), scalability, I decided to try producing a heat-map with no text labels, and thus each cell could be as small as a single pixel.
div.figure: A prototype of a condensed heat-map, where x-axis represents input and y-axis represents output.
div.p: The color scale is a discrete scale, where each step is determined by the quantiles of the weight distribution. The x-axis represents the input text, and the y-axis represents the output text, with each cell representing the amount of attention paid for that pair (output paid to input). The good news here is that the attention distribution is relatively easy to understand at a quick glance. The downside is that cells that are not part of a larger trend (you may notice a lone red spot near the top of the heat-map, approximately a quarter of the way through the x-axis) are harder to make out, as the cells are so small. Further, the distribution is contextless — we don’t know the structure of the input text or what words these high weights are associated with. In the example above, we understand that the model focused primarily on the beginning of the article, but we can’t tell whether that is good or bad without seeing the text.

To remedy this, I decided to also display the input text, with the input text highlighted according to the maximum of the weights it received. This also solves concerns (1) and (3) for the conventional heat-map.
div.figure: The input text corresponding to the heat-map above, where each token is highlighted according to its max attention weight received.
div.p: By putting these two together (along with the output text for reference), we can gain a better understanding of how the model arrived at its summary. A viewer can now map the attention distribution shown in the heat-map to text in the input sequence by looking for patches of similar color intensity.
div.figure: A prototype static visualization including both heat-map and highlighted text.
div.p: To get a better sense of how this visualization pattern would play out, I built a light web-page that allows users to cycle through different input / output examples. The gif below shows several of these.
div.figure: The described visualization pattern over several input / output sequences.
div.p: More exploration (inside and outside of this pattern) will need to occur, but this seems promising!
Lots to get done this next week. Here’s what’s in my plan:

ol.li: Continue working on data collection and cleaning up the TensorBoard plug-in. Move beyond the proof-of-concept front-end and show that meaningful visualizations (perhaps extremely basic ones) can be generated using the plugin back-end as a data source.

Read more into the model provided by See et al. (2017), as well as related work, to gain a better understanding of the architecture and function/behavior of attention. A closer study of the works cited in my second blog post will be a good starting point. The better I understand this mechanism the more equipped I’ll be to create meaningful visualizations.
Continue prototyping static visualizations, move on to interactive visualizations. Acquire feedback from peers for both.

div.p: Thanks for reading!

li.a: See, Abigail et al. “Get To The Point: Summarization with Pointer-Generator Networks.” ACL (2017).
Rikters, Matīss, Mark Fishel, and Ondřej Bojar. “Visualizing neural machine translation attention and confidence.” The Prague Bulletin of Mathematical Linguistics 109.1 (2017): 39–50.

h4.span: Team members: Dawei Shen, Pinyi Wang, Xukai Liu

div.span: Social Media Predicts Stock Price (StartUp Mode)

span.span: This week, we tried to use tf-idf and seq2vec to process news headlines as input to our LSTM

div.span: model to predict UP/DOWN for APPLE stock price.

Categorize tweets with date and correlated stock price

Accuracy on predicting Up or Down
Accuracy on predicting Stock Price (TODO)
TF-IDF: 60.7% accuracy predictin UP/DOWN on test set with 273 total data points and 9/1 train-test split
Seq2Vec: 53.6% accuracy predicting UP/DOWN on test set with 273 total data points and 9/1 train-test split

span.b: Things that may impair the precision of prediction

A, is, of, for, the
Tweets talking about fruit apple instead of the company

Crawl more data for more companies and longer duration
Add financial
Add the competitor companies stock prices and tweets news as part of the input.

div.p: Nearing 4 weeks in — I’ve finally got a foothold in the development process. Over this past week I’ve been looking through TensorBoard and TensorFlow source-code and documentation in an attempt to develop a foundation for plugin development.

li.a: TensorBoard Documentation

ul.li: TensorBoard Source Code and Existing Plugins
Developing a TensorBoard Plugin (a simple example)

ol.li: Understand the structure of a TensorBoard Plugin, specifically how the architecture of the Attention Plugin should look like.
Design and write the data fetching layer.

div.p: In TensorFlow, data from iterations of training / evaluation is stored as a set of summaries. These can take the form of any tensor, including text, image, scalars, or time series. These are written to disk as the computation graph is executed. Each ‘summary’ takes the form of a Summary protocol buffer, which holds, in addition to the data stored, critical identifying information (tags and metadata). A plugin can then read summaries associated with particular tags and sessions from disk to serve to the TensorBoard front-end via a plugin back-end, where a visualization is rendered.
Following Developing a TensorBoard plugin, the Attention Plugin with have three primary components:

ol.li: Data API layer. This is what allows users to capture relevant summaries from within their models.
Plugin backend, which serves said summaries.
Frontend, where the visualizations are displayed.

div.p: Unlike commonly used plugins such as the scalar and histogram plugins, the Attention Plugin consumes 3 distinct values: the input text, the decoded output text, and the attention matrix that correlates the two. Initially, I attempted to store these all in a single Summary protobuf, where the first two rows of the encapsulating matrix would contain the text, and the rest would contain the attention weights. This results in a mixing of string and float types in a single Tensor, which is not valid (to my knowledge) in TensorFlow. I then realized I could store these separately, each in their own summary, and retrieve them via an identifying name. The resulting architecture is shown in the diagram below.
div.figure: The architecture of the Attention Plugin.
div.p: I decided to make the output text an optional summary, as models don’t necessarily need to decode (via Viterbi, Beam Search, or otherwise) an output sequence while training. The input text and attention matrix are still valuable, as summary statistics (e.g. coverage, important words, etc) can be gleamed without the decoded text.
div.figure: Data API Layer highlighted in green.
div.p: As the TensorBoard authors suggest, the data API layer, defined in attention_summary.py, provides two methods for creating Summary protobufs, which can then be written to disk via a FileWriter. The first is via a TensorFlow op, which can be thought of as a node in the computation graph, that produces a Summary when the graph is executed. The second is by directly creating the protobuf, which allows for data to be saved outside the execution of a TensorFlow session. I’ve implemented both of these. There is a separate method for each of the three datum used by the plugin (input text, output text, attention matrix), and each of the three summary datum are tagged differently (e.g. name/attention_input_summary, name/attention_output_summary) in order to allow for distinguishable retrieval later.
An example of the usage of both methods can be found in attention_demo.py.

I suspect the work completed this week was the biggest hurdle in terms of time:code ratio. I would not be surprised if I had to revisit the work done here in order to clean things up or fix small bugs. However, with this understanding and architecture nailed down, I expect implementation of the rest of the plugin will come at a faster pace. With that said, three tasks stand as immediate goals for the next week.

ol.li: Modify my forked repository of the summarization model created by See et al. (original found here) to produce and save the appropriate summaries for the Attention Plugin. I’ve already started looking into this, and expect to have to fiddle around with the training / evaluation scheme in order to grab an appropriate amount of data.
Implement the backend of the Attention Plugin.
Begin prototyping visualizations (pen & paper) and acquire preliminary feedback.

div.p: Until next time.

source.subtitle: Stories by Halden Lin on Medium
source.title: Stories by Halden Lin on Medium

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: A big part of our work for setting up a baseline is the creation of a reasonably good dataset for training and evaluating extractive text summarization. Our goal was to build a dataset with all sentences from the articles marked with binary labels indicating whether or not they were part of the extracted summary.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: We used the DailyMail and CNN story dataset, which is meant for abstractive summarization, to build our own dataset. The data set includes automatically-parsed lines from news articles, as well as a few bullet point highlights for each article. These highlights are not sentences directly from the article, but are overall a decent indicator and considered to be one of the most useable datasets out there (if for no other reason than sheer volume of data).

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: To build our data set, we used a toy metric roughly based off of ROUGE-N, with the understanding that we would only need a way of relative ranking for each sentence.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: The procedure to generate the data set was as follows:

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Read in a single .story file from the abstractive dataset into highlights and sentences.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Post-process sentences- in the original data, new lines do not correspond exactly with sentence endings. Additionally, some sentences are originally split arbitrarily by new lines. We do an additional split by the regex (?<=[.?!])\s+ (whitespace with period, question mark, or exclamation mark lookbehind), but sentence “re-joining” is off by default, as some sentences in the original dataset do not end with punctuation.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Score each sentence with our metric.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Tokenize each sentence and highlight.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Build unigram, bigram, and trigram lists.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Count the number of matches between the sentence and all the highlights, giving more weight to bigram and trigram matches and also weighting by word length.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Sort sentences by score.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Let S be the number of sentences and H be the number of highlights. The algorithm picks up to min(1, floor(S/2)) sentences as part of the summary. It picks at least the H sentences with the highest scores. After sentence H is picked, subsequent sentences will only be picked if their score was at least (80+3*X)% of the previously-picked sentence’s score, where X is the number of sentences currently picked. This is effectively a fairly arbitrary metric to pick the most likely sentences roughly in accordance with the size of the abstractive summary, while also allowing for particularly similar sentences to both be chosen for completeness.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: All data input and output with UTF-8 encoding.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Output format:

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: <#> <SENTENCE PLAINTEXT>

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: # is either 0 = normal sentence in the article, 1 = sentence chosen as part of extractive summary, 2 = original abstractive summary (should not be touched by model, only left there for human reference).

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Overall, we think our data set is generally reasonable and makes sense. Nonetheless, there are a number of weaknesses with both extractive models in general and this specific type of dataset (including some problems which derive from the original abstractive dataset).

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Key weaknesses of data set:

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: In the original data, highlights do not always correspond to actual information in the article. For example, this short story has four highlights that are all new information: 008fc24ca9f4c48a54623bef423a3f2f8db8451a.story.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Frequent formatting problems - sentences that don’t terminate with punctuation, repeated sentences, bugged unicode characters, etc.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Key weaknesses specific to extractive summarization:

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Articles that are particularly short are effectively impossible to meaningfully summarize with extractive techniques.

li.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre;

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Some sentences in articles contain the same content with slightly different wording. In these cases, we decided to choose both sentences, with the idea that post-processing could take care of highly-similar sentences, but a model could not be expected to accurately distinguish between two such sentences if they have different labels.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: The Baseline Model:

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: For our baseline combinatorial approach, we did a simple Maximum Coverage Problem implementation. The Maximum Coverage Problem is a classic NP-complete problem. Given a collection of n sets, the goal is to maximize the number of chosen (or “covered”) elements while only choosing k of the sets (where k < n). It’s very straightforward to reduce summarization to this problem. The sentences in the document are the sets, and the vocabulary of the document represents the “universe”, or the elements in the sets. The goal is to cover as many words as possible while picking the same number of sentences as in the labelled summary. The intuition is that sentences with more words capture more semantic meaning, and once a word is listed in the summary, that word need not be considered again. This reduction makes some intuitive sense, but two main aspects must be refined. First, not all words are equally meaningful. Some words, like “a”, “the”, or “and”, have little semantic content, while named entities and other important words have much higher semantic content. Second, we should at least account for sentence lengths -- instead of constraining the algorithm to pick the same number of sentences, we should constrain it to the same word count. This two additional criteria turn the problem into the Budgeted Maximum Coverage Problem: elements in the sets have specified values, and the sets have specified costs. The new objective is to maximize the total value of the covered elements while remaining with a given budget.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Of course, this problem is NP-complete, so it may seem like a strange choice to model summarization with. There are two approaches to this. First, a simple greedy algorithm achieves an approximation of ~63%, which means that the greedy algorithm is guaranteed to get at least 63% of the value of the optimal solution. For the standard MCP, the greedy algorithm just chooses the set with the most uncovered elements until no more sets are allowed. For the budgeted MCP, the approximation algorithm is slightly more complex. See Khuller et al. for a detailed look at it -- the algorithm is slightly more work, but still very understandable, and achieves the same approximation bound. We can also formulate the problem as an Integer Linear Program (ILP) and use an ILP solver to generate optimal solutions on realistic instance sizes. This works because the documents and sentences are both small.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: For now, we are using the greedy algorithm for the standard MCP. As a simple metric, we used the number of correct chosen sentences divided by the number of chosen sentences in total (correct means that the gold standard also picked that sentence). With a basic MCP approach, we had an accuracy of 0.218. This was measured on a small sample of 2000 stories. In order to approximate a weighting scheme, we use a stop list to simply remove common articles and other semantically empty words. With this small modification, we had an accuracy of 0.2328.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: We plan to extend this to a better baseline model in the next few days. We will formulate the problem as an ILP and pass it to an ILP solver for an optimal solution. We will also implement a more sophisticated weighting scheme. One idea is to use some of the labelled data as training data (right now, we don’t train) to build a weight matrix for common words -- we can build this matrix with a logistic regression, using n-gram (probably unigram) similarity as the loss function.This will hopefully give us a more reasonable baseline model.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: Evaluation Framework:

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: For now, we’re using a simple accuracy metric. We plan to switch to ROUGE, which counts n-gram similarity (ROUGE measures recall, not precision). We will work with the ROUGE-2.0 Java package or pyrouge, depending on which language we are working with.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: black; font-family: Arial; font-size: 11pt; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: 400; text-decoration: none; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; white-space: pre;

div.span: So to summarize our goals for the next week, we will improve this baseline model by formulating the problem as an ILP and we may implement a weighting scheme (if that’s too complicated, we’ll save it for the advanced model). We will also build a baseline neural model. Then, we’ll flesh out our evaluation framework using ROUGE metrics, train/test using more of the corpus, and have detailed error analysis.

h4.span: Team members: Dawei Shen, Pinyi Wang, Xukai Liu

div.span: Social Media Predicts Stock Price (StartUp Mode)

This week, we experimented with crawling data by querying from Twitter website, but we had some struggles finding the meaningful data set. Firstly, the Twitter API does not support fetching tweets prior than 7 days, so we have to write bash scripts and use a crawler to strip data from website, which is comparatively slower.

We tried to query keywords like Apple, iPhone, iPad. Lots of tweets we got are not in English, so we used language detection tools to filter out tweets in other languages. Unfortunately, there are too much giveaway and advertisement flooding on the platform. Some examples are:

blockquote.span: "Microsoft planning to launch Surface Pro 6 in first quarter of 2017"
"KFire TV Giveaway: Win a Microsoft Bluetooth Mouse. http://kodifiretvstick.com"
"Microsoft Releases The 'Studio', Its First Desktop Computer"

div.span: Therefore, for out strawman model #1 we decide to use the relative news headlines under twitter search query.

We searched companies' names like Google, Microsoft, Tesla to find relative new headlines and use unigram (bag of words) to put it in a decision tree model with random forest mechanism to predict the price go UP or DOWN. We had mixed results using this model. This is just our first attempt to see whether the twitter data is useful to predict the movement of future stock prices.
AAPL GOOG MSFT AMZN
Next week, we'll try to use deep neural network as predictive model and expand our input to the user feedback of the product from general users.

div.h3: Towards a Better Understanding of Neural Networks: Visualizing Attention in Sequence-to-Sequence Models
div.p: The idea of ‘attention’ was first introduced to the sphere of natural language processing by Bahdanau et al. (2014) in Neural machine learning by jointly to align and translate. The idea is fairly straightforward: if we have an encoder-decoder model, at each decoding time-step we generate a vector of attention weights corresponding to each of the encoding units. That is to say, when generating each output token, we pay ‘attention’ to certain parts of the input sequence. Intuitively, this is much how we as humans fixate on parts of text to perform tasks such as summarization or question answering.

In Machine Learning, neural networks have always been a sort of black box. We know they work incredibly well in certain contexts, but its often difficult to understand why they work so well. The following quote sums up the need for interpretability quite well.

strong.em: “I believe the most important direction for future research is interpretability.

blockquote.em: The attention mechanism, by revealing what the network is “looking at”, shines some precious light into the black box of neural networks, helping us to debug problems like repetition and copying. To make further advances, we need greater insight into what RNNs are learning from text and how that knowledge is represented.”

div.blockquote: - Abigail See, PhD - Stanford University, ‘So, is abstractive summarization solved?’ from Taming Recurrent Neural Networks for Better Summarization
div.p: Visualization provides an avenue for interpretability by mapping the behavior of the complex networks to easy-to-understand visual encodings.

Although I am not aware of any papers dedicated to the visualization of attention, examples can be readily found in both published literature and online blogposts. For each example below, I’ll point out strengths and weaknesses. Ultimately, I hope to show that there are improvements we can make that can augment the interpretability of the workings of seq2seq attentional models.
div.figure: Bahdanau et al. (2014). An attention visualization for a seq2seq problem (in this case, translation). Whiter cells represent higher attention.
div.p: The encoding scheme used by Bahdanau et al. (2014) themselves, heat-maps were the most common encoding of attentional data I found. While making the task of relative correlation lookup efficient, these have a couple of weaknesses.

ol.li: Hard to scale. With tasks involving large input or output (e.g. a hundred or more tokens) the size of the heat-map quickly gets out of hand. Scrolling greatly decreases the effectiveness of a visualization with respect to analysis tasks.

Difficult to read. We generally don’t read in a token-per-line format. Furthermore, source text is rarely in a token-per-line format — we lose insightful information that could be drawn from analyzing the original structure of the text.

div.figure: Rikters et al (2017). The input sequence is seen on top — output on bottom. Thicker lines denote higher attention.
div.p: Less common, but interesting nonetheless. This kind of flow-map suffers from problems similar to those of heat-maps. One could also argue that the thinness of the lines and their cross-hatch nature hinder interpretability.
div.figure: See et al. (2017). Interactive visualization of attention
div.p: Interaction solves many of the issues of the static visualizations surveyed above. We retain the structure of both the input and output text, and lookup is quick and efficient. There is a trade-off, however. We are only able to view the attention of a single word at a time, and as a result it is hard to get a sense of the overall coverage or structure of attention.

In particular, abstractive summarization. Summarization is a particularly interesting use case of attention because of the requirement of the condensing of text. The hypothesis is that good abstractive models will be able to cover the majority of the original document. Here I note the difference between extractive and abstractive summarizations. The former involves selecting pieces of the original text, verbatim. The latter involves compressive paraphrasing.

Until recently, most of the work in text summarization has revolved around extractive summarization (See et al. 2017). However, the rising prevalence of recurrent neural networks has allowed for further focus in abstractive summarization. Attention has played an important role in improving results. Below is a brief list of relevant work.

p.a: Rush, Alexander M. et al. “A Neural Attention Model for Abstractive Sentence Summarization.” EMNLP (2015).
Nallapati, Ramesh et al. “Abstractive Text Summarization using Sequence-to-sequence RNNs and Beyond.” CoNLL (2016).
Hasselqvist, Johan et al. “Query-Based Abstractive Summarization Using Neural Networks.” CoRR abs/1712.06100 (2017): n. pag.
Paulus, Romain et al. “A Deep Reinforced Model for Abstractive Summarization.” CoRR abs/1705.04304 (2017): n. pag.
See, Abigail et al. “Get To The Point: Summarization with Pointer-Generator Networks.” ACL (2017).

div.p: While visualizations of attention are helpful in shedding light on the workings of seq2seq models, summarization models in particular have trouble leveraging this window.

ol.li: We care about where attention falls just as much as what it falls on. We hope to maximize coverage. This is not currently addressed in any interactive visualizations I am aware of.
We have large input sequences. As discussed in “A survey of related work,” this is particularly problematic for static visualizations.

div.p: With this in mind, I propose areas for improvement in both interactive and static visualizations.
With interactive visualizations, two things.

One. Coverage is the aggregated attention over a sequence of output tokens. An example given by See et al. can be seen in the figure below. Perhaps allowing brushing to visualizing the aggregate attention over a phrase or sentence can help us understand attention in a more global context.
div.figure: See et al. (2017). Example of coverage.
div.p: Two. Extraction vs Abstraction: Ideally, we want our model to learn how to abstract rather than extract. 1:1 exact match attention is less interesting to see than seeing attention to groups of words. Perhaps emphasizing / de-emphasizing can this in visualizations can help aid understanding of models.
With static visualizations, there are two analysis tasks that we wish to optimize for.

ol.li: Summary. What is the overall structure of the attention (e.g. coverage).
Value. Which input words are attended (i.e. focused on) by each output timestep?

div.p: It is difficult to design an effective static visualization that lends itself well to both of these tasks. Perhaps we need a set of visualizations. For example, one visualization might afford better performance for summary analysis, while another might afford better performance for value analysis. In addition, these static visualizations can incorporate ideas described in previous section.

Additionally, attention visualizations thus far have been for specific examples. Perhaps there a way we can look across examples to better understand the behavior of these neural networks. Derived metrics for attention or coverage could be useful in better understanding and diagnosing these models.

My hope is that addressing these items in both interactive and static visualizations will allow us to better reason about neural networks. In particular, I hope the result can be used as a valuable tool for error analysis, even beyond hyperparameter tuning. Insights could be gleamed that motivate additions or constraints or mechanisms to optimize coverage (e.g. See et al. (2017)) or abstraction.

ol.li: Develop a TensorBoard plugin that allows for the static and interactive visualizations described in Where to?
Acquire feedback from students / researchers in the Allen School.

div.p: I intend to leverage existing models to retrieve data. For example, that provided publicly by See et al. (2017). The dataset used by them is a modified CNN/Daily Mail Dataset [Hermann et al. (2015), See et al. (2017)] — a collection of articles and bullet point summaries.

ol.li: Explore and implement aggregate, cross-example visualizations as described in Where to?
Release a beta of the TensorBoard plugin on github and acquire feedback there.

li.a: See, Abigail et al. “Get To The Point: Summarization with Pointer-Generator Networks.” ACL (2017).
Karpathy, Andrej, Justin Johnson, and Li Fei-Fei. “Visualizing and understanding recurrent networks.” arXiv preprint arXiv:1506.02078(2015).
Hasselqvist, Johan et al. “Query-Based Abstractive Summarization Using Neural Networks.” CoRR abs/1712.06100 (2017): n. pag.
Nallapati, Ramesh et al. “Abstractive Text Summarization using Sequence-to-sequence RNNs and Beyond.” CoNLL (2016).
Paulus, Romain et al. “A Deep Reinforced Model for Abstractive Summarization.” CoRR abs/1705.04304 (2017): n. pag.
Rush, Alexander M. et al. “A Neural Attention Model for Abstractive Sentence Summarization.” EMNLP (2015).
Bahdanau, Dzmitry, Kyunghyun Cho, and Yoshua Bengio. “Neural machine translation by jointly learning to align and translate.” arXiv preprint arXiv:1409.0473 (2014).
Hermann, Karl Moritz et al. “Teaching Machines to Read and Comprehend.” NIPS(2015).
